conclusion: Determine the time t for the conductor rod to slide down until it reaches its maximum speed.
The magnetic field B is perpendicular to the plane of the rails and directed downward.
The induced emf in the conductor rod is given by emf = B L v.
The current I in the circuit is given by I = B L v / (R + r).
The force on the conductor rod due to the magnetic field is F_B = B^2 L^2 v / (R + r).
The net force on the conductor rod is F_net = m g sin θ - B^2 L^2 v / (R + r).
At maximum speed, the net force is zero, leading to v_max = m g sin θ (R + r) / B^2 L^2.
The equation of motion for the conductor rod is m g sin θ - B^2 L^2 v / (R + r) = m a.
Rewriting the equation as a differential equation: d v / d t = g sin θ - B^2 L^2 v / (m (R + r)).
Separate variables and integrate: ∫(0 to v_max) d v / (g sin θ - B^2 L^2 v / (m (R + r))) = ∫(0 to t) d t.
The time t is given by integrating the velocity equation.
The time t is t = m (R + r) x / (1/2 m g sin θ L^2 - B^2 L^3 / (2 (R + r)) x).
Simplifying, the final answer is t = m (R + r) x / (1/2 m g sin θ L^2 - B^2 L^3 / (2 (R + r)) x).
